stem: A 45-year-old patient is complaining of abdominal pain related to meals that poorly respond to antacids. He has a significant weight loss and early satiety for 6 months. On examination, there is a mass over the epigastrium which is approximately 3cm. The breath test for H. pylori is negative. What is your diagnosis?
disc:
Most patients with gastric cancer present with an incurable disease.

The most common symptoms are weight loss and abdominal pain. Dysphagia is a common symptom in patients with more proximal tumors. They may have early satiety due to tumor mass or pyloric obstruction due to a distant mass. Occult GI bleeding can give rise to anemia.

The most common physical finding is a palpable epigastric mass which indicates advanced disease.
